awd_titl_txt: Conference: Improving the Greenland Data Ecosystem for Scientific Insight
awd_abstract_narration:
Climate change is causing rapid warming in Greenland and on the Greenland Ice Sheet. Changes in Greenland have impacts around the globe, from adding freshwater to ocean ecosystems in the North Atlantic to raising sea levels in Florida and other faraway places. Scientists are studying Greenland changes and producing important and useful data and science tools. As the amount of data increases and the number of tools available to help with science expands, it is critical that people producing, using, and applying Greenland-focused data are coordinating with each other. This workshop will bring together people who create and use Greenland data so that they can discuss data needs and outline ways that tools can be made more useful. They will also identify gaps in knowledge, data, and tools that need to be addressed. In this way, the workshop will help the Earth sciences community to work together to ensure that data is usable and used, and to create new knowledge more effectively. Follow-through on workshop recommendations will also help Earth scientists work effectively with other researchers and non-scientists, like decision makers or local townspeople. 

Greenland-focused research is crucial for addressing issues including ocean ecosystem transformation, rising global sea levels, and Earth system links that may increase or decrease how quickly climate impacts appear. The National Science Foundation and others have supported key data, tools, and programs related to Greenland research. As these projects mature, coordination and community discussion are required to ensure that projects are working together, gaps in data, tools, and workflows are identified, and there is a shared vision to support efficient and effective research across a broadening group of participants. This 2-day (virtual and in-person) interactive workshop will gather data and tool creators and users to discuss needs, identify open opportunities, and chart the developments in Greenland data and tools to support the next decade of science in service to society. The workshop will enhance coordination in the Greenland Earth science community, develop community recommendations for more effective and efficient data-to-insight and insight-to-application workflows, and ensure the Earth science community is well prepared for collaboration with other researchers and nonscientists. These improvements will have widespread positive societal benefits, connected closely with urgent topics such as sea level rise and ecosystem change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As the Arctic climate system undergoes rapid change, research plays a key role in knowledge-generation to serve communities, scientists, policymakers, and others. With the expansion of Greenland-focused research, the National Science Foundation and other funding agencies have supported development of key data, tools, and programs. As these projects mature, coordination and community discussion is required to ensure that projects are working together, gaps in data, tools, and workflows are identified, and there is a shared vision for future development that can support efficient and effective research across a broadening group of participants. This 2-day interactive workshop (including in-person and virtual agendas) brought together members from the Greenland data and research community to share plans, discuss open opportunities, and chart the necessary developments in Greenland data and tools to support the next decade of science in service to communities in Greenland and across the globe.

We view the workshop as one activity within a larger continuum that should include data use, data sovereignty, and co-production discussions hosted in Greenland. To assist in continuing and expanding these discussions, participants support funds remaining after the workshop were used to send two workshop representatives to the “Mapping the Arctic” meeting in Nuuk during April 2023. This activity included sharing a poster of draft goals and recommendations, initiating conversation, seeking input from attendees, and then synthesizing the response back for inclusion in this report. Draft workshop goals and recommendations were also shared for comment at the March 2023 Future of the Greenland Ice Sheet Science (FOGSS) meeting in Atlanta, Georgia.

We hope that attention to and action on these goals and recommendations can create more efficient and effective pathways for data creation and use and streamlined data-to-insight and insight-to-application workflows, supporting critical outcomes across many areas of research. Successful convergence and co-production frameworks, which are increasingly needed to address complex scientific and societal challenges, also depend on the preparedness and tools of the contributing groups. Acting on the workshop recommendations should prepare the Greenland data and research community for accelerated collaboration.

This workshop was particularly timely given the release of the first Greenland National Research Strategy. We note, however, that elements discussed in the workshop cover a range of geographic areas, and issues are covered that are Greenland-specific, Arctic-specific, and pertain to wider research data issues. Considerations specific to Greenland include language complexities, with English, Danish, and Greenlandic commonly used, and with three dialects of Greenlandic across the island; large geography coupled with few residents (population ~57,000 total); and important actors across Greenlandic and Danish institutions and governments. Greenland also holds specific interest regarding data and research because it has one of the world’s few ice sheets, containing ~7.4 m of potential sea level rise, increasing its global importance and making it unique within the Arctic.

Workshop attendees were tasked to work together to: 

  • Map the ecosystem of Greenland natural science data archives, tools, and workflows; 
  • Identify and prioritize gaps in the data and tool ecosystem; 
  • Brainstorm routes to close gaps in the data to insight system; and 
  • Bring judgment and prioritization to identified routes.

Workshop Outcome Goals & Recommendations

Increase Greenland partnership and support Greenland leadership

  • Support Greenlandic priorities, leadership, and partnerships.

  • Engage with Isaaffik and Arctic Hub.

Ensure FAIR and CARE is applied in data creation

  • Increase training and advocacy to adopt metadata standards and tools.

Develop open data systems

  • Improve open data discovery and access, emphasizing systems to make Greenland data findable.

  • Provide meta/data training for non-academics, including Greenland non-research people.

  • Promote data accessibility, including for Greenland residents.

Support data use by researchers and educators

  • Incentivize researcher engagement with Greenlandic institutions, especially in education.

  • Empower researchers to use existing data and contribute to data repositories.

Increase data synthesis

  • Support creation of community consensus datasets and synthesized data products.

The final workshop report and the summary slides are available in English and Greenlandic. These and other workshop materials have been archived and are available at the National Science Foundation Arctic Data Center (https://arcticdata.io/, https://doi.org/10.18739/A2C824G6X).
